msContents.summary: An unidentified scribe completed this very rare, complete, prosimetrical biography entitled Ḥāl-i Baygum Samrū of Samru Begam, (ca. 1745, r. 1778–1836), ruler of the principality of Sardhana, on Monday, 11 February 1841, just 5 years after her death. Comprised of twenty-two brief chapters, it opens by recounting her husband, German mercenary Walter Reinhardt Sombre (ca. 1720-1778), and how the Mughal ruler Shāh ‘Alām II rewarded him with lands of the Durranis forces that he defeated, within which he established the principality in 1773. Referring to her to by the honourific Zīb al-Nisā Baygum throughout, then work continues to describe Begum Samru's ascension upon her husband's death in 1778, her formidable character, and major events in her life up until her death.

msItem.colophon: برگ ۳۴ر (folio 34a): تمام شد بتاری یانزدهم فبروری سنه ۱۸۴۱ ع، روز دوشنبه
Completed by an unidentified scribe on Monday, 11 February 1841.
msItem.note: This work may possibly be a prose redaction of a metrical biography of Begum Samru compposed by her munshī, Lālah Gūkul Chand, before her death (British Library Add. 25830), in which he states in his preamble that he took on the task after the discovery that a prior prose version reportedly authored by Jai Singh Rai had been lost. Nevertheless, this text covers the final decade of her life apparently not found in the other manuscript. D. N. Marshall also notes another manuscript held in the Saravasti Bhandar Library, Udaipur, described by M. L. Menaria as also authored by Gokul Chand; however, whether that volume might also comports with the others awaits investigation.

supportDesc.support: Thin-weight, ivory-coloured, externally sized and polished paper probably handmade in the Indian subcontinent, with ~11 laid lines per cm and no discernible chain lines.
supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in Hindu-arabic numerals on the upper-left corners of the a sides throughout.
supportDesc.collation: Primarily quaternions. 4IV(32)1II(vii). Catchwords on the lower-left corners of the b sides throughout.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 1 column with 10 lines per page. Ruled with a misṭarah hand guide.

handDesc.handNote: Written in clear black nasta‘līq with red subheaders.

physDesc.additions:
Table of Contents: Listed on the two loose bifolia inserted before the right flyleaves, (loose leaves 1a to 4b).
Inscriptions: The fifth right flyleaf a side (f. va) bears a descriptive title of the work in bold nasta‘līq with the name of former owner Colonel George William Hamilton, likely in the hand of his an assistant Muhīn Dās.
Bookplates: Left cover interior: Bibliotheca Lindesiana with pencilled shelfmark 2/K, and Hamilton MSS No. 696.

binding.p: Probably rebound in Multan for former owner Colonel George William Hamilton.

Unsupported sewing at 2 stations, spine lined with cotton fabric, with the excess width adhered to the second and second-to-last flyleaves. Edges trimmed, but endbands omitted. Covered in semi-limp full maroon semi-limp goatskin leather. Flyleaves tipped onto the cotton fabric, with the excess width adhered as hinges connecting the text to the cover, but without full pastedowns, then reinforced with overlaid, thin transluscent tissue.
binding.decoNote: An octagonal paper label on the right cover bears the title in black nasta‘līq
binding.condition: Handle binding with caution. In fair condition with the right cover detached. Boxed.

physDesc.accMat: Two bifolia tucked between the left pastedown and first right flyleaf a side (f. ia) bear a list of the contents written in black nasta‘līq in machine-made paper

history.origin: Presumably completed by an unidentified scribe in the Indian subcontinentin the Monday, 11 February 1841

provenance.p: Subsequently acquired by Colonel George William Hamilton (1807-1868) who served in India from 1823 to 1867, latterly as Commissioner in Delhi. He acquired over a thousand Indian and Persian manuscripts, from which the British Museum selected 352, now held in the British Library.

history.provenance: Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880) purchased the remainder of Hamilton's collection in 1868.

provenance.p: Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript catalogue by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s, concisely published as Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript description by Jake Benson in 2022 with reference to the volume in hand.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.
